image.altText: A swarm of journalists and people holding cameras surround Matt Wright as he leaves court.

props.synopsis: Now that the trial of celebrity crocodile wrangler Matt Wright is over, the ABC can reveal what happened while the jury was out of the room.

title.children: What the jury in the Matt Wright trial did not hear

image.altText: a group of young people exercising in the bush

props.synopsis: In the face of growing scrutiny over its punitive crime policies, the Northern Territory government says its early intervention program and "boot camps" are "making a real difference".

title.children: 'Boot camps' and early intervention: The NT's plan to prevent youth crime

image.altText: The exterior of the Alice Springs courthouse, with blue sky in the background.

props.synopsis: A 24-year-old Indigenous woman who died after being hit by a car following a violent attack by her partner was failed by police multiple times in the lead-up to her death, the Northern Territory coroner has heard during a week-long inquest.

title.children: Police overlooked warnings before woman's DV-related death, inquest hears

image.altText: A close-up of man's hand holding a canister labelled as "pepper spray" in each hand. A couple of other bottles on the table.

props.synopsis: From Monday, September 1, Northern Territory residents can buy and use pepper spray for personal protection in a 12-month trial by the NT government. Let's break down the rules.

title.children: Want to buy pepper spray in NT? Here's what you need to know

image.altText: Alfreda Dunn in front of a pre paid power meter in Alice Springs

props.synopsis: Northern Territory public housing tenants struggle to keep the power on amid calls for the government-owned provider to reduce tariffs on prepaid electricity.

title.children: Prepaid electricity customers struggle to keep the power on

image.altText: East Arnhem Live crowd

props.synopsis: This weekend marks the fourth East Arnhem Land community music festival, with the line-up featuring 10 bands from across the region.

title.children: The music festival 700km down a dirt track in East Arnhem Land

image.altText: A group of Aboriginal mourners walking through a coles supermarket, while holding branches.

props.synopsis: Almost 80 Northern Territory lawyers have written to the government calling for "external oversight" in the investigation into Kumanjayi White's death in custody, and for the officers involved to be stood down during the probe.

title.children: Lawyers call for police involved in Kumanjayi White's death to be suspended

image.altText: A hand holding a phone with an online gambling app open on the screen.

props.synopsis: Financial Counsellors are warning of catastrophic impacts of unregulated gambling, known as "scambling", spreading like wildfire in First Nations communities. New data shows $2.8m in all types of scam losses were reported by First Nations people in the first six months of this year.

title.children: The 'predatory and unethical' scam targeting Australia's most vulnerable

image.altText: A swarm of journalists and people holding cameras surround Matt Wright as he leaves court.

props.synopsis: Celebrity crocodile wrangler Matt Wright is found guilty on two counts of attempting to pervert the course of justice, after a month-long Supreme Court trial.

title.children: Matt Wright guilty on two counts of hindering chopper crash investigation

image.altText: Nic Naitanui, Matt Priddis, Dean Cox, Mitchell Brown and Scott Lycett stand arm in arm singing West Coast Eagles' AFL team song.

props.synopsis: Mitch Brown will forever be etched in the game's history, but experts, advocacy groups and fans pushing for systematic change say this is not a time for celebration.

title.children: 'Homophobia permeates every square centimetre' of the AFL

image.altText: Jimmy Li with the Chinese peace statue.

props.synopsis: Though hailed as a "beautiful call for peace", this 60kg bronze statue of a young girl has languished in a suburban garage for nearly a year.

title.children: 'Silent, unspeakable humiliation': Australia's first Chinese comfort woman statue

image.altText: balding man with glasses and a moustache sits with a white and black scarf around his neck

props.synopsis: Ahmed al-Rahawi was killed in a Thursday strike in Sanaa along with several ministers, the rebels said in a statement on Saturday.

title.children: Israeli air strike kills Houthi rebel prime minister in Yemen

image.altText: The lower half of two standing people. One person has swollen and bandaged feet.

props.synopsis: Queensland hospitals have reported being overwhelmed with patients suffering from respiratory illnesses as experts sound the alarm about growing vaccine mistrust.

title.children: RATs are potentially skewing official case numbers this flu season

image.altText: Composite image of six victims of jumping castle tragedy with school signage as background

props.synopsis: Former jumping castle operators have joined calls from Hillcrest victims' families for improved regulation of the inflatable amusement device sector.

title.children: Calls for law change so 'no other family endures the pain' of Hillcrest tragedy

image.altText: silhouette of a man holding an upside down flag with red background, union jack and white southern cross stars

props.synopsis: "Sovereign citizens" believe Australian laws do not apply to them. That's where pseudolaw comes in.

title.children: 'I do not consent': How pseudolaw supports 'sovcit' ideas

image.altText: Australian tennis player Alex de Minaur pumps his fist after a point at the US Open.

props.synopsis: Australian tennis star Alex de Minaur is a win away from a third US Open quarterfinal after taking down injured German Daniel Altmaier, while Daria Kasatkina's run ends with a loss to two-time Flushing Meadows champion Naomi Osaka.

title.children: De Minaur holds his nerve to advance at US Open, with Kasatkina beaten by Osaka

image.altText: Andriy Parubiy sitting in a red chair at a microphoned desk.

props.synopsis: Former Ukrainian parliamentary speaker Andriy Parubiy has been killed in the western city of Lviv, and a manhunt is underway for his killer.

title.children: Former Ukrainian parliament speaker shot dead in 'horrific murder'

image.altText: Runners on a road

props.synopsis: An estimated 35,000 participants are taking part in the Sydney Marathon today, with this year's race marking the city's first under the Abbott World Marathon Majors series.

title.children: Ethiopian wins Sydney Marathon in fastest time recorded in Australia

image.altText: A soldier in a trench, firing a gun, while another soldier looks on behind holding a grenade.

props.synopsis: Australian troops are among a group of allies helping train Ukrainian soldiers in England. Despite technological advances in war, sometimes it's about getting back to basics.

title.children: Amid Russia's invasion, some Ukrainians have to 'fight like it's the 1940s'

image.altText: A police car on the side of a road.

props.synopsis: Police confirm the deaths of four people in 24 hours on Queensland roads.

title.children: Horror night on Queensland roads tips road toll over 200

image.altText: A montage of an old two-storey stone mansion, a rolls-royce car, a sheep and a boy wearing a VR eyemask.

props.synopsis: The drought in western Victoria is forcing sheep farmers to the wall, but amid the dirt and dust are green shoots of optimism and ingenuity that will change farming here forever.

title.children: Farmers innovate to beat drought in former 'wool capital of the world'

image.altText: Blading man with glass and long white beard smiles in garden setting

props.synopsis: The pressure to maintain a facade of success led Mic Whitty down a slippery slope to debt and homelessness. The kindness of friends and strangers helped him find his way back.

title.children: A gambling spiral all but broke Mic. His grandfather's war diary was his path out

image.altText: Tom Gleeson on the set of Hard Quiz gesturing behind him with a serious expression.

props.synopsis: Another week, another opportunity to show us your substandard trivia skills. Too mean? Too bad.

title.children: Convinced you can nail this quiz? Be my guest

image.altText: A woman and man holding on to wheelie bin handles next to a pile of coffee grounds.

props.synopsis: Melbourne's love affair with coffee is causing thousands of tonnes of ground coffee waste — leading to methane emissions. One social enterprise is tackling this, combining it with animal waste — another large emitter — to improve sustainability.

title.children: Grounds from your morning coffee are helping to reduce emissions

image.altText: An Australian rugby player raises her arms in the air after scoring a try during a World Cup match.

props.synopsis: The Wallaroos can still qualify for the Women's Rugby World Cup quarterfinals but their fate is in the balance after a thrilling 31-31 draw with the United States.

title.children: Wallaroos still alive after World Cup draw with United States

image.altText: Image of a woman wearing a blue sweater, sitting in a cafe courtyard while reading a book.

props.synopsis: As symptoms of burnout rise, an increasing number of women are turning to reading retreats as a salve for stress.

title.children: Reading retreats offer women time to devour a good book in nature

image.altText: Max Gawn of the Demons competes with Lloyd Meek of the Hawks for the AFL ball in a ball-up

props.synopsis: Predicting who is going to win during each round of the AFL is tough, and even computer algorithms struggle to do better than the luckiest human.

title.children: Why predicting winners in the footy is a lot harder than we think

image.altText: An Italian tennis player claps his racquet to applaud the crowd after his win at the US Open.

props.synopsis: World number one Jannik Sinner tells the world he's not a machine after overcoming tough Canadian challenger Denis Shapovalov to continue his title defence at Flushing Meadows.

title.children: Sinner says he's 'not a machine' after dropping set against Shapovalov

image.altText: Reece Walsh throws a pass off the ground in a Brisbane Broncos NRL game.

props.synopsis: The Brisbane Broncos climb into the top four heading into the final round of the NRL season after beating North Queensland 38-30 in Townsville.

title.children: Broncos climb into top four despite schoolboy errors in 'bizarre game'

image.altText: A group of people holding red and white flags with a fire in the background.

props.synopsis: The building was set alight on Friday night which caused the area to turn an eerie orange colour.

title.children: Three dead after angry mob sets fire to parliament building in Indonesia

image.altText: woman takes selfie with a highland cow

props.synopsis: Tasmania recorded its highest number of visitors for the June quarter on record — but what attracts tourists to a colder climate?

title.children: Tourists shun the sun for a cool Tassie experience

image.altText: Woman with dark hair looking serious

props.synopsis: After 45 minutes of false suspense, Thailand's constitutional court did exactly what was expected. Her dismissal flings the country into political instability.

title.children: Shinawatra's dismissal highlights limits of Thailand's fledgling democracy

image.altText: A woman with red hair across her face kneels down in the street. She wears a yellow dress.

props.synopsis: Dozens of high-quality releases from all genres hit the shelves/streaming services in August, giving us a nasty case of choice paralysis. We've covered 10 of the month's finest albums, covering hip hop, indie rock, neo-soul, electro, pop and more.

title.children: The 10 albums we couldn't stop listening to in August

image.altText: Australian F1 driver Oscar Piastri taks a corner in his McLaren car during qualifying for a grand prix.

props.synopsis: Australia's Oscar Piastri is starting from pole position ahead of teammate Lando Norris at the Dutch Grand Prix at Zandvoort. Here's what you need to know about the race.

title.children: What time does the F1 Dutch Grand Prix start? How can I watch?

image.altText: Old, rusty, red ute on the right hand side. Red dirt and clear blue sky.

props.synopsis: In the remote town of Andamooka, even native plants struggle to survive. Scientists are trying to find a solution to food security, a problem shared by outback residents and future space travellers.

title.children: Outback SA is likened to Mars. Would it be easier to grow plants there?
